field_reports.summary: IRN: Fire - 04-2025 - Explosion and Fire at Shahid Rajaei Port, Hormozgan2025
field_reports.description:
Approximate Time of Incident: Around 11:55 AM  
Source of Incident Announcement: Crisis Management  
Location of Incident: Shahid Rajaei Port, Hormozgan  
Number of Secondary Explosions: 4  
Shahid Rajaei Port is the largest and most important commercial port in Iran, located in Bandar Abbas, Hormozgan. It plays a key role in the transit, export, and import of goods for the country. Equipped with advanced facilities, the port handles millions of tons of cargo and connects the North-South transport corridor. Due to the storage and export of chemical and petrochemical materials, it is highly sensitive.  The high risk of incidents at Shahid Rajaei Port is attributed to the storage of large quantities of flammable materials such as sulfur and other chemicals, weak safety standards in some sections, and non-compliance with strict guidelines for hazardous material storage. Past incidents of fires, explosions, and toxic gas releases highlight the urgent need for improved risk management and safety infrastructure to prevent future accidents.

results.name: IRN: Fire - 04-2025 - Explosion and Fire at Shahid Beheshti Port, Hormozgan2025

field_reports.description: According to the report of the relief and rescue organization, heavy rainfall began on Wednesday in the provinces of Ilam, Kermanshah, North Khuzestan, South and West Lorestan, NorthWest part of Chaharmahal & Bakhtiari, South West of West Azerbaijan, West Kurdistan, and on Thursday in North and East Khuzestan, south of Lorestan, north and west of Chaharmahal &Bakhtiari continued. Heavy rain has caused the sudden rise of river water levels, flooding of canals and seasonal rivers, and widespread flooding of roads. 8 provinces include West and East Azerbaijan, Ilam, Kurdistan, Kermanshah, Gilan, Ghazvin, Lorestan, and 27 cities need relief and rescue services. 3people have died so far.

field_reports.summary: IRN: Earthquake - 2023-01 - Safa EQ West Azarbayejan 2023
field_reports.description: Based on the national seismological report, an earthquake of 5.9 magnitudes on the richter scale occurred at a depth of 7 km in the area of Safa in Firouragh district, Khoy county on Saturday 28 January 2023 at 21:44 followed by 72 aftershocks felt the greatest of 4.5 magnitudes at 18:11. Overall, 261,387 people affected, 1,017 injured and 3 died so far across 2 cities and 86 villages. Many urban residential buildings collapsed or were partially damaged in Safa district and Khoy county. Also, residential buildings in 70 villages have been destroyed from 20 to 80 percent based on the governate general office of W-Azarbayejan. The electricity and gas supply were cut in the affected region. The telecommunication means disrupted at least in four villages namely Chavoshqoli, Asgarabad, Aland, and Kalvan. The severity of the situation intensified by the heavy snowfall and zero temperature. The fear of aftershocks hindered affected households to return their houses and they prefer to be settled in the 40 camps provided across the affected region by the IRCS.

results.summary: According to national seismological report, an earthquake of 5.9 magnitudes on the richter scale occurred at a depth of 7 kilometers in the area of Safa  10 Km to Khoy.. 3 death and 500 casualties have been reported so far.261.378 (77.920) are living in the affected regions. 2 cities and 86 villages.
results.name: IRN: Earthquake - 2023-01 - Safa EQ West Azarbayejan 2023

field_reports.description: According to the Iranian Seismological Center, a 5.4 magnitude earthquake hit Firoragh village of Khoy city in West Azarbayejan province of North-Western Iran on 18 January 2023 at 13:19 p.m. at depth of 12 km local time. A 3.6 magnitude earthquake was happened at the same point earlier at 13:19 p.m. Twenty-one aftershocks are reported so far, the biggest is 4.2 at 18:25 p.m. (see: http://irsc.ut.ac.ir/newsview_fa.php?&eventid=188976&network=earth_ismc__). The nearest village named Vaar is 10 km away from the epicenter. The same region was also hit at 5 October 2022 by a 5.4 Richter magnitude earthquake that resulted in 1,308 injured people. The epicenter of the previous quake is named Morteza Gholi Kendi, the most hit village, located in Khoy City. The affected area consists of one province and one city (55 villages) with a total population of approximately 10,284 households (41,426 people). Firoragh district is the most hit area in Khoy city. People in the cities of Salmas, Chaldoran, Chaypareh, Poldasht, and Uroumia have felt the tremor. Iran is a prone country to several disasters specially earthquake due to the active faults in several regions of the country. The activated fault in this region which caused this earthquake is called Siyah Cheshme-Khoy.

results.summary: according to relief and rescue, organization reports a 5.9 Richter occurred at 13:19 P.M 18 January in western Azerbaijan,Khoy and Zar abad are the most eaffected areas. the assesments are going to be continued.
results.name: IRN: Earthquake - 2023-01 - western Azarbaijan

field_reports.summary: IRN: Earthquake - 2022-10 - West Azerbaijan-The Town of Khoy
field_reports.description:
West Azerbaijan, The city of Khoy Earthquake, Iran

Date: Wednesday Morning, October 5, 2022

According to the Iranian Red Crescent Society, a magnitude 5.4 earthquake has struck northwestern of Iran, on Wednesday morning, October 5, 2022 at 3:51 local time close to the city of Khoy in the province of West Azerbaijan (Dazaj diz district). The quake that hit at a depth of 10 kilometres in West Azerbaijan province, with 42 aftershocks has injured 1127 people, and 126 people hospitalized so far as well, according to the latest information from IRCS. Two provinces (West Azerbaijan, East Azerbaijan) and eight Cities (Khoy, Salmas, Chaypareh, Tasooj, Marand, Jolfa, Shabestar, and Tabriz) were affected by the earthquake. The Iranian Red Crescent Society began its response following the earthquake and has deployed its operational and assessment teams to the quake - affected areas immediately after the earthquake. (23 assessment and 44 operational teams). 53 villages were observed by the IRCS assessment Teams. The quake and its aftershocks damaged 200 houses in 53 affected villages. Also, the electricity and water have been cut in some villages.   

  Red Crescent actions following the earthquake:

  • Preparedness of the province of East Azerbaijan and Zanjan
  • Deploying IRCS assessment and Relief and Rescue Teams from the city of Khoy, Salmas and Chaypareh County for the primary assessment.
  • Coordinating the deployment of IRCS helicopters for sending assessment teams to the region.
  • Providing temporary shelter with 1335 tents, shortly after the earthquake.
  • Providing 2000 Blankets, 1335 tents, 786 ground mats, 6500 food packages
  • IRCS Psychosocial Support (SAHAR) teams deployed to the region: A team with 14 persons

results.summary:
According to the Iranian Red Crescent Society, a magnitude 5.4 earthquake has struck northwestern of Iran on Wednesday morning, October 5,2022 at 3:51 local time close to the town of Khoy in the province of West Azerbaijan (Dazaj diz district). The quake that hit at a depth of 10 kilometres in West Azerbaijan province with 30 aftershocks has injured 767 people, and 74 people hospitalized so far, according to the latest information from IRCS. 2 provinces (West Azerbaijan, East Azerbaijan) and 8 Cities (Khoy, Salmas, Chaypareh, Tasooj, Marand, Jolfa, Shabestar andTabriz) were affected by the earthquake.The Iranian Red Crescent Society began its response following the earthquake. The IRCS has deployed its operational and assessment teams to the quake affected areas immediately after the earthquake. (23 assessment teams). 53 villages were observed by the IRCS assessment Teams. The quake and its aftershocks damaged 200 houses in 53 affected villages. Also, the electricity and water have been cut in some villages.                                                                                      Red Crescent actions following the earthquake:

  • Preparedness of the province of East Azerbaijan and Zanjan
  • Deploying IRCS assessment and Relief and Rescue Teams from the city of Khoy, Salmas and Chaypareh for the primary assessment of the scene.
  • Coordinating the deployment of IRCS helicopters for sending assessment teams to the region.
  • Providing temporary shelter with 90 tents, shortly after the earthquake.
  • Providing 330 Blankets, 125 groundsheets, 140 food package in temporary shelter.
  • IRCS Psychosocial Support (SAHAR) teams deployed to the region: A team with 14 persons
results.name: IRN: Earthquake - 2022-10 - West Azerbaijan-The Town of Khoy

countries.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of

field_reports.description:
Iran is located in the Middle East with the population of 85 million in 2022. After Saudi Arabia, Iran is the second largest country in the region with area of about 1,628,763 km. Due to the locations of Alborz and Zagros mountains in the Iranian plateau (East-West and Northwest-Southeast respectively) which acts as a barrier, the movements of clouds from North and West are blocked, which effectively dividing the country into arid (65%) and semi-arid (20%) regions. The climatic diversity of the country due to the different altitudes and subtropical high pressure are the reasons for the wide range of temperature differences throughout the country with coldest being less than -30°C and hottest being more than 50°C.  

Annual average of rainfall is about 250 mm which is about one third of the average global rainfall although north part of Iran receives rainfall more than 1600 mm; however, in several places specifically in the dry regions where rainfall could be less than 50 mm per year. From this rainfall, about 71% is lost to evaporation this is about 3 times more than the global average.  

Iran, like other countries in world is now facing serious water shortages. Increase of water demand, decrease in water levels in groundwaters and frequent drought are some of the indicators of the problems the country is now facing. These issues are mainly caused by population growth, inefficient farming leading to high water usage and low crop yield, and finally the mismanagement in the water sector. It is estimated that the water available per capita would reach 816 m3 by 2025 indicating absolute scarcity. 

In 1962, the total available water per capita was 5900 m3 but with the population growth (almost 60 million in 55 years), it is now about 1750 m3 well below the world’s average of 7000 m3. According to UN development program, with the current population growth of 1.3% annually, the total renewable water resource per capita would reach the worrying amount of 816 m3 by 2025 (Lehane, 2014). According to Falkenmark indicator (Falkenmark, 1989) which is the most common indicator of water stress on a nation, the current 1750 m3 available water per person is almost to the level of stress category, however this could reach to absolute scarcity if the trend continues for the coming years. 

Based on a research published in https://iranopendata.org, 97% of the total area of Iran is affected by drought due to decreased rainfall and increased temperatures. This database has concluded, through the analysis of meteorological indicators over one-year and ten-year periods, that only in five provinces (Kordestan, West Azerbaijan, Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad, Hamadan, and Lorestan) the percentage of drought-affected areas are less than 90%. The provinces of Alborz, Tehran, and Qom are mentioned as having 100% of their area affected by drought in 2022. This is while heavy rainfall in 2022 has resulted in only 10 to 20% of the areas in Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad and Chaharmahal and Bakhtiari provinces being affected by mild drought. The research, based on the classification of drought severity from "mild" to "extreme," indicates that 69% of Iran's area is affected by "severe" or "extreme" drought. It has also introduced the three provinces of Golestan, Ardabil and Semnan as the provinces with very severe drought in a 10-year period. In the published report, referring to the report of the National Drought Center about the main watersheds, the 10-year situation in the "Eastern Border" basin was evaluated as more critical than other basins and it was emphasized that more than 99% of the area of this basin was involved in various degrees of drought. The report has mentioned the drought crisis in Iran beyond climatic drought and caused by high consumption and harvesting of renewable water resources for agricultural and horticultural purposes. 

  

 

A significant national symbol of climate-related drought known to almost everyone is Lake Urumia. At its greatest extent, Urmia is one of the largest hypersaline lakes on Earth. According to NASA, Lake Urmia nearly dried out in the fall of 2023 and continues to gradually transform into a dry salt flat. In 1995, Lake Urmia reached a high-water mark; then in the ensuing two decades, the lake level dropped more than 7 meters (23 feet) and lost approximately 90 percent of its area. Consecutive droughts, agricultural water use, and dam construction on rivers feeding the lake have contributed to the decline. The deteriorating condition of the lake affects the livelihood of the surrounding communities, particularly those dependent on agriculture and fishing. It has also contributed to health problems, as the exposure to airborne salt and dust particles from the dry lakebed can lead to respiratory issues. Furthermore, the lake, its islands, and surrounding wetlands comprise valuable habitat and are recognized as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve. The area provides breeding grounds for waterbirds such as flamingos, white pelicans, and white-headed ducks, and a stopover for migratory species. However, with low lake levels, what water remains becomes more saline and taxes the populations of brine shrimp and other food sources for larger animals. (https://www.earth.com/image/lake-urmia-is-transforming-into-a-salt-flat/)  

  

Figure 1: Lake Urmia is transforming into a salt flat! (Credit: NASA Earth Observatory) 

 

 

Figure 2: Observed changes of the Urmia Lake area from 1990 to 2020 based on satellite images. https://www.esri.com/. 

 

Drought can have widespread and significant impacts on various aspects of people's lives. Some of the key areas affected by drought include: 

1-      Water Supply: 

·         Drinking Water: Drought reduces water availability, leading to lower water tables and drying up of wells. In urban areas, water scarcity may result in restrictions on water usage, affecting daily life. 

2-      Economy/ livelihood: 

·         Impact on Agriculture Industry: Reduced agricultural productivity affects the income of farmers, disrupts supply chains, and can lead to increased food prices. 

·         Job Losses: In rural areas heavily dependent on agriculture, job losses can occur due to reduced farming activities and related industries. 

3-      Health: 

·         Waterborne Diseases: Drought can result in contaminated water sources, increasing the risk of waterborne diseases like cholera and dysentery. 

·         Malnutrition: Crop failures and reduced agricultural productivity can contribute to malnutrition, particularly in children and vulnerable populations. 

·         Stress and Mental Health: The uncertainty and challenges posed by drought, including economic difficulties and food insecurity, can contribute to stress, anxiety, and mental health issues in affected communities. Social cohesion may also be strained as people cope with the impacts of the drought. 

4-      Social and Community Dynamics: 

·         Migration: Drought-induced economic hardship can lead to internal or cross-border migration as people seek better living conditions and opportunities. 

·         Conflict: Competition for limited resources such as water and grazing land can result in conflicts within communities and between different user groups. 

5-      Wildlife and Ecosystems: 

·         Habitat Loss: Drought leads to the drying up of wetlands and rivers, impacting the habitats of aquatic species. Terrestrial ecosystems may also suffer, affecting wildlife populations. 

·         Wildfires: Dry conditions increase the risk of wildfires, causing damage to ecosystems, loss of biodiversity, and posing threats to human settlements. 

Addressing these challenges often requires a multi-faceted approach that includes water conservation, sustainable agricultural practices, early warning systems, social safety nets, and policies that promote resilience and adaptation to changing climate conditions. Additionally, community engagement and awareness play crucial roles in building the capacity of individuals and communities to cope with and adapt to drought. 

 

The Iranian government has issued several drought warnings in recent years, urging people to conserve water and take measures to reduce water usage.

field_reports.description: At around 12:30 on the second of Khordad, parts of the 11-storey commercial office building in Abadan, known as the Twin Towers of the Metropolis in the Telenji area of Omidi, collapsed for unknown reasons. As soon as the incident was reported to the Red Crescent Society, 5 search and rescue operations teams and rapid response, 2 rescue dogs teams with 7 rescue vehicles from Khorramshahr, Mahshahr and Shahedgan cities deployed to field and evacuation and safety enhancement launched. Due to the scale and severity of the incident, the number of operational forces present on the scene was increasing every hour, so that by the evening of the same day, the Red Crescent Society with 92 rescue forces in the form of 19 teams was able to carry out rescue operations. At present (May 29th), this operation is being carried out with the participation of more than 247 Red Crescent task forces and the use of 2 helicopter and 51 operational vehicles.

countries.society_name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
countries.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of

field_reports.description: Iran faces a range of environmental challenges from high temperatures, pollution, flooding, and vanishing lakes. In April 2021, the Iranian Meteorological Organization warned of an "unprecedented drought" and rainfall levels that were substantially below longterm averages. The amount of rainfall in Iran's main river basins from September 2020 to July 2021 was, in most places, substantially lower compared with the year-earlier period. Iran experiences frequent droughts and faces the prospect of more extreme conditions brought about by climate change. According to current assessments, parts of Iran are facing a rainfall which has had an observed impact on vegetation and agriculture. Of particular concern is that these drought impacts have been observed in northeastern Iran in areas bordering Afghanistan. The Iranian Red Crescent Society (IRCS) reports that 29 of 31 provinces, and especially seven – South Khorasan, Kerman, Sistan Balochistan, Hormozgan, Khuzestan, Isfahan, Khorasan Razavi – have been severely affected by the drought. The lack of safe and sufficient water supply for drinking, hygiene, agriculture, animal husbandry, and electrical power is having a devastating and increasingly unsustainable strain on households’ health, income in addition to encouraging negative social trends and coping mechanisms.

field_reports.description: According to the Iranian Meteorological Organization, heavy rainfalls with thunderstorms started on 01 January 2022 in  almost 30 provinces and lasted for 4 days. Over 34K people affected in 19 provinces. The Iranian Red Crescent Society has supported 34,071 flood-affected people in 19 provinces. Relief consignment including food, blanket and ground sheet sent to Chabahar city 0f Sistan and Baluchestan province, on Wednesday. The National Society’s aid workers have rendered various relied services to people and households when the rainfall and floods impacted the areas. So far, the Iranian Red Crescent has provided emergency shelter to 5,168 people in eastern province of Sistan and Baluchestan and Hormozgan. Transportation routes are still blocked and the relief items were deployed by the NS air rescue choppers to Konarak and Chabahar cities. IRCS’ rescuers evacuated 90 people to safe areas. Injured people received outpatient services and those in need were transported to medical centers. Heavy flash flood resulted in killing 10 people in Chabahar, Darab, Lamerd, Beyram, Sirjan and Mehrestan counties. Aid workers pumped water out of 374 houses and recovered 201 vehicles. Relief interventions by the IRCS have covered 309 areas including urban, rural, mountain and nomadic areas. The NS senior management has paid a field visit in the affected areas to assess the situation and speed up the response operation.

field_reports.description: According to the Iranian Seismological center a 6.4 magnitude earthquake hit Ghale' Ghazi district, near to Fin city in Hormozgan province of South Iran at 15:37 local time. So far, 88 aftershocks (the biggest one with 6.2 Richter at 21:20 local time has hit the region). The affected area includes one city and 137 villages. Around 9,121 households (34,394 people) residing in the affected area. Surrounding affected cities are Haji Abad, Bandar Abbas and Roudan, felt also in Kerman and Fars provinces. According to the EMS, 99 persons injured and one dead reported as a result of power pole collapse. People in the affected areas are terrified and assumed to stay outside over night. Slight cracks on the walls are seen (mainly the villages close to the epicenter, Fin district, Sarzeh and Rezvan villages). The most damaged villages are West Gishan, Aab Shirin, Zartoo Bala & Paeen, Roodshoor, Gohareh Chelo and Chahkal.

countries.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of

field_reports.description:
The Iranian climate is mostly arid or semi-arid and it is heavily affected by depleting water resources, as a result of rising demand, salinization, groundwaters overexploitation, and increasing drought frequency. The country, where 
groundwater is the primary source of water, has a long history of inefficiency in its water distribution network, particularly in the agricultural sector. Despite not experiencing food insecurity, Iran faces paramount challenges in safeguarding long-term water access during the dry spell. All sectors that rely on the water are exposed, from agriculture to power production and public water supply. Currently, from 2 to 20 million people are at high to medium risk of drought-related 
impacts. On top of poor precipitation during the 2020-2021 winter, high temperatures have caused more snow to melt, reducing the amount of water stored for later use during the drier months (i.e., late spring and summer).
Since the beginning of the drought onset, research units, the media, and public authorities have been emphasizing the potential severity with time. On 10 July 2021, the First Vice President of Iran, Eshaq Jahangiri stressed that the Islamic Republic of Iran requires national solidarity and integration to overcome challenges and to pass crises.

results.summary:
The evolving situation in Afghanistan is increasingly creating new potential drivers and triggers for cross-border displacement. The 2021 Afghanistan Humanitarian Needs Overview identified 18.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance with 6.3 million being in extreme or catastrophic severity of needs; this figure is now likely to have increased due to the recent events in country. The situation remains uncertain in Afghanistan and may evolve rapidly.

Afghanistan faces an alarming humanitarian emergency and a worsening economic crisis, both likely to be further compounded by the approaching winter season. Almost half the population faces colossal humanitarian needs wrought by a combination of crises: displacement, devastation of COVID-19 pandemic, drought, acute food shortages, a fractured health system, poor access to services, and restrictive social norms. More than 558,000 Afghans have been internally displaced by the conflict since January 2021, 80 per cent of these newly internally displaced are women and children.

According to the drought declaration by the Afghanistan government of 22 June 2021, the country’s wheat crop will be reduced by nearly two million tons, and more than three million livestock are in danger of perishing due to a lack of fodder and water. IPC new projections for the period June – November 2021 estimates that, 2,742,741 Afghans are likely to be classified in Phase 4 (catastrophic) in terms of Food Insecurity and 6,719,607 in Phase 3 (emergency). The compounding impacts of drought and conflict which escalated in July and the first half of August have exacerbated the hard living conditions in a country that is also grappling with COVID-19 and poverty. Access to banking services has been severely constrained, with cashflow crippled. Collapse of Afghanistan’s economy would result in catastrophic consequences for vulnerable Afghans, including potentially fueling cross-border movements for economic reasons.

Therefore, based on analysis of the ongoing social, economic, political and security situation in Afghanistan, it is assessed that a further political and humanitarian deterioration in the country is likely to result in new population movements to neighbouring countries. A potential worst-case scenario – utilized by the UNHCR and inter-agency partners - envisages the arrival of an additional 515,000 Afghan refugees into neighbouring countries before the end of 2021.

Any major population movement will require an immediate and sustained humanitarian intervention in neighbouring countries. This will include critical life-saving humanitarian assistance at border points and in designated sites in coordination with respective authorities.

There are up to six million Afghans living outside of Afghanistan – in Europe, Asia Pacific and the Middle East - following several decades of instability in the country. New arrivals in 2021 will join more than 2.2 million registered refugees who have fled previous waves of insecurity, instability and violence to neighbouring countries. There are a further 3 million Afghans with varying status including many irregular migrants, who have been hosted in the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Islamic Republic of Pakistan over the past four decades. It will be important to maintain humanitarian assistance and protection for both new arrivals, and those previously displaced, as well as host communities.

Beyond the scope of this Emergency Appeal, there may also be onward movements and humanitarian needs in secondary countries, with Afghans taking routes to Turkey, Greece and the Western Balkans region. It will be critical to both monitor these trends and developments, as well as to be prepared and ready to provide increased principled humanitarian assistance and protection along existing migratory routes to those on the move– irrespective of their status – and to host communities in secondary countries.
results.name: Regional Population Movement - Afghanistan | Preparedness and Response

field_reports.description: According to the reports of EOC center of Iranian Red Crescent Society, a magnitude 5.5 earthquake hit Sankhast province in North Khorasan at 3:34 local time. 36 villages have been damaged after the earthquake which 9 were reported with the highest damages.

field_reports.description: According to the reports, since 29 April and as the Meteorological organization warned the heavy rain, the flash flood hit provinces of Iran causing 10 deaths and many damages to the villages. Provincial branches assessed the situation and relief operations started as the early warning was announced.

field_reports.description: According to the emergency call by the IRCS EOC in Bushehr province at 11:16 on Sunday 18 April 2021 regarding a strong tremor in Genaveh city, the 5.9 magnitude earthquake was confirmed by Geophysics Institute of Tehran University. The epicenter was notified by the Relief & Rescue Organization EOC to the provincial branch and the first rapid response teams from Genaveh relief posts were deployed to the field. 10 more teams were called on to start assessment in the area. The EOCs in the neighboring provinces activated to be standby in case of major damages. The video conference from HQ EOC set up constantly with the province.

field_reports.description: according to the local  primary report an earthquake hit  the south west at the border of 4 provinces and with 10 km depth at 6:09 AM.  no death have been reported so far. 20 search and rescue teams  that include 65 volunteers and 20 operational staff have deployed to the field. rescuer have assessed 31 villages in the affected areas. in khuzestan province 12 operational team deployed to rural  areas and provided relief services to 330 household in 24 villages.over 251 affected people have received relief items such as tent, blanket, canned food,rice, sleeping mats.73 houses in rural areas were seriously damaged.

field_reports.description: According to the seismological center, a 5.6 magnitude earthquake hit Sisakht city, near Yasouj, capital of Kohgilooye-Boyerahmad province on Wednesday Februrary 17, 2021 at 22:05 local time, at a depth of 10 km. Over 147 villages have been affected with a population of 24,291 (7020 HHs). ^ after-shocks reported so far. In some roads, the power, water and gas is cut off at the early hours of the incident.

countries.society_name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
countries.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of

field_reports.description: According to the reports of IRCS Relief and Rescue Organization, since 22 January winter snow affected 19 Provinces in Iran. 37 cities and villages have been reached by Iranian Red Crescent to assist 4,897 people. 597 relief workers including 175 surge teams participated in operations. While 37 people were evacuated to safer places, 338 people were also sheltered in emergency situation. 20 people were referred to medical clinics and 1 dead due to the bad weather. 392 vehicles were extricated from snow. Relief items distributed among affected people including 92 blankets, 1,795 kg plastic sheets, 475 food parcels, 97 bottled water, 44 kg date and 379 biscuits.

countries.society_name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
countries.name: Iran, Islamic Republic of

field_reports.description:
Heavy rainfalls hit 8 provinces in south and western part of Iran (Ilam, Boushehr, Khuzestan, Fars, Ghazvin, Kohklouye-Bouterahmad, Golestan, Lorestan) with over 121 urban and rural areas since 28 November 2020.
Iranian Red Crescent Society activities to respond to the orange-level flood in affected areas included early warning, alert to teams standby, -warned by Iran Meteorological Organization, air rescue standby, EOC centers activation, preparing the risk map related to climate conditions in the areas at risk, field visit by the head of IRCS Relief and Rescue Organization to the flood affected areas in Khuzestan and having video conference sessions with provinces active in flood operations as well as with the auxiliary provinces.
